hawaiian_text: ‘O Hō‘ae‘ae ma ‘Ewa ka ‘āina, ma laila lāua i  launa kino ai me ka moe ‘ana iho ā loa‘a ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o. A hāpai ‘o Pōka‘ī iā   Nāmakaokapāo‘o, ho‘i akula ‘o Kauluakaha‘i i kona  ‘āina, noho ihola ‘o Pōka‘ī me kona hāpai, a ma hope, hānau. Ma kēia hānau ‘ana, he ‘ilihune loa ‘o  Pōka‘ī a me kāna keiki ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o.
gemma-3-27b-1temp-cli-manual-aistudio_tr: Hō‘ae‘ae in ‘Ewa was the land, there they had intimate relations, even to the point of conceiving Nāmakaokapāo‘o. And Pōka‘ī carried Nāmakaokapāo‘o, and Kauluakaha‘i returned to his land, and Pōka‘ī remained with her pregnancy, and later, gave birth. With this birth, Pōka‘ī and her son Nāmakaokapāo‘o were very poor.
gemma-3-27b-1temp-cli-manual-aistudio_co:
**Paragraph 2:**
• This paragraph details the conception and early circumstances surrounding the birth of Nāmakaokapāo‘o, establishing the initial setting and socio-economic conditions of the protagonist’s early life. The narrative shifts focus from introducing the characters to detailing the events leading to and immediately following his birth.
– The location, Hō‘ae‘ae in ‘Ewa, is significant. ‘Ewa, generally, is associated with westward travel, and in Hawaiian cosmology, often represents the direction of the setting sun and, symbolically, the land of the ancestors (Po). Hō-‘ae-‘ae (breathing/sighing repeatedly) suggests a place of respite, perhaps even a secluded or hidden location, fitting for the intimate act described. This could also be a poetic reference to the breath of life being given.
• The phrase “launa kino ai me ka moe ‘ana iho” is a euphemistic and poetic way of describing sexual intercourse and subsequent conception. “Launa kino” literally means “joining bodies,” while “me ka moe ‘ana iho” emphasizes the consummation of that union, leading directly to pregnancy. The use of such indirect language is common in traditional Hawaiian storytelling, particularly when dealing with sensitive topics.
– The direct result of this union is “loa‘a ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o” – the obtaining/receiving of Nāmakaokapāo‘o. This phrasing frames the child not merely as a consequence, but as a gift or a blessing, even before his birth.
• The narrative then details the separation of Kauluakaha‘i from Pōka‘ī and the unborn child. He “ho‘i akula ‘o Kauluakaha‘i i kona ‘āina” – returned to his land. This suggests he had responsibilities or obligations elsewhere, potentially related to his chiefly status (as established in the previous paragraph). His departure leaves Pōka‘ī to carry the pregnancy alone.
– This abandonment, or at least temporary separation, is a recurring motif in Hawaiian mythology, often signifying a challenge or hardship the protagonist must overcome. It also highlights the strength and resilience of the female characters, who frequently bear the burden of raising children in difficult circumstances.
• Pōka‘ī’s remaining “me kona hāpai” – with her pregnancy – emphasizes her solitary state. The word “hāpai” itself is significant, meaning both “to carry” (physically, the child) and “to support” (emotionally and materially).
– The subsequent birth is described simply as “ma hope, hānau” – later, birth. This brevity underscores the focus on the *consequences* of the birth, rather than the birthing process itself.
• The final sentence, “Ma kēia hānau ‘ana, he ‘ilihune loa ‘o Pōka‘ī a me kāna keiki ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o,” establishes the socio-economic hardship faced by mother and son. “’Ilihune” means “poor” or “destitute.” This poverty is crucial to understanding the narrative arc.
– The introduction of poverty at this stage is not merely a detail of circumstance; it’s a foundational element of Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s character development. In traditional Hawaiian society, hardship often served as a catalyst for demonstrating strength, resourcefulness, and mana (spiritual power). This sets the stage for Nāmakaokapāo‘o to potentially challenge societal norms or overcome obstacles through his own abilities. This could be an allegorical reference to the dismantling of the 'Ai Kapu system, where the ali'i (chiefs) were often wealthy and the maka'āinana (commoners) were poor. The story may be a metaphor for the commoners rising up against the ali'i.
– The repetition of Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s name reinforces his importance and foreshadows his central role in the unfolding narrative. The name itself – Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o (the eyes of the pāo‘o fish) – continues to be intriguing. The pāo‘o fish is known for its keen eyesight and ability to navigate murky waters, suggesting Nāmakaokapāo‘o may possess similar qualities of perception and resilience. The “eyes” (maka) could also symbolize insight or spiritual awareness.
raw_response:
<translation>
Hō‘ae‘ae in ‘Ewa was the land, there they had intimate relations, even to the point of conceiving Nāmakaokapāo‘o. And Pōka‘ī carried Nāmakaokapāo‘o, and Kauluakaha‘i returned to his land, and Pōka‘ī remained with her pregnancy, and later, gave birth. With this birth, Pōka‘ī and her son Nāmakaokapāo‘o were very poor.
</translation>

<commentary>

• This paragraph details the conception and early circumstances surrounding the birth of Nāmakaokapāo‘o, establishing the initial setting and socio-economic conditions of the protagonist’s early life. The use of such indirect language is common in traditional Hawaiian storytelling, particularly when dealing with sensitive topics.

This suggests he had responsibilities or obligations elsewhere, potentially related to his chiefly status (as established in the previous paragraph). His departure leaves Pōka‘ī to carry the pregnancy alone.
– This abandonment, or at least temporary separation, is a recurring motif in Hawaiian mythology, often signifying a challenge or hardship the protagonist must overcome. It also highlights the strength and resilience of the female characters, who frequently bear the burden of raising children in difficult circumstances.
• Pōka‘ī’s remaining “me kona hāpai” – with her pregnancy – emphasizes her solitary state. The word “hāpai” itself is significant, meaning both “to carry” (physically, the child) and “to support” (emotionally and materially).

– The introduction of poverty at this stage is not merely a detail of circumstance; it’s a foundational element of Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s character development. In traditional Hawaiian society, hardship often served as a catalyst for demonstrating strength, resourcefulness, and mana (spiritual power). This sets the stage for Nāmakaokapāo‘o to potentially challenge societal norms or overcome obstacles through his own abilities. This could be an allegorical reference to the dismantling of the 'Ai Kapu system, where the ali'i (chiefs) were often wealthy and the maka'āinana (commoners) were poor. The story may be a metaphor for the commoners rising up against the ali'i.
– The repetition of Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s name reinforces his importance and foreshadows his central role in the unfolding narrative. The name itself – Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o (the eyes of the pāo‘o fish) – continues to be intriguing. The pāo‘o fish is known for its keen eyesight and ability to navigate murky waters, suggesting Nāmakaokapāo‘o may possess similar qualities of perception and resilience. The “eyes” (maka) could also symbolize insight or spiritual awareness. </commentary>
reference_translation: Hō‘ae‘ae is the place in ‘Ewa, where the two  met in person and slept together and conceived  Nāmakaokapāo‘o. When Pōka‘ī became pregnant,  Kauluakaha‘i went home to where he came from,  and Pōka‘ī throughout her pregnancy and later gave birth. When she gave birth, Pōka‘ī and her  child, Nāmakaokapāo‘o lived in poverty.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 2:**• Hō-‘ae‘ae (to make smoothe) in ‘Ewa (error,  misjudgment) is where Kauluakaha‘i (m) and Pōka‘ī  (f) met, slept together, and where Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o was born. When Pō-ka-‘ī became pregnant, Ka ulu-a-kaha‘i left and returned to his home in Kahiki papa-ia-lewa. Pō-ka-‘ī was single and destitute when  she gave birth to Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o.
